content.text: As a fully remote team, maintaining security from our home offices is critical to protecting ClearTriage's data and maintaining our FedRAMP compliance. The good news? Most remote security boils down to a few simple habits that quickly become second nature.
Your laptop is the gateway to ClearTriage's systems. Keeping it secure is your first line of defense against potential threats.

items: **Keep your operating system and software updated** - Those update notifications aren't just annoying pop-ups. They often contain critical security patches. Enable automatic updates whenever possible.
**Use full disk encryption** - This is required for FedRAMP compliance. On Mac, FileVault should be enabled. On Windows, use BitLocker. Pete can help you verify this is set up correctly.
**Lock your screen** - Every time you step away, even at home. It takes one second and prevents unauthorized access if someone enters your space.

content.text: Set your computer to automatically lock after 10 minutes of inactivity. It's a simple setting that provides continuous protection.
Working from home doesn't mean working in isolation from security risks. Your environment matters more than you might think.

items: **Be aware of who can hear your conversations** - Video calls from coffee shops might seem harmless, but discussing patient data or system details in public is a security violation.

**Never discuss ClearTriage business in public spaces** - This includes phone calls in shared spaces, working on sensitive documents where others can see your screen, or leaving printed materials where they might be seen.
**Consider your background on video calls** - Whiteboards, sticky notes, or screens visible in your background could inadvertently share sensitive information.

content.title: Real Scenario
content.content: You're at a coffee shop and need to join a quick team call. Instead of discussing the details of our AWS infrastructure where others might overhear, excuse yourself to your car or reschedule for when you're in a private space. A minor inconvenience prevents a major security incident.

content.title: Remember
content.text: Working remotely gives us flexibility, but with that comes the responsibility to maintain security wherever we choose to work. When in doubt, err on the side of caution.
